com.informix.lang

Class IfxToJavaType

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.informix.lang.IfxToJavaType

  • public final class IfxToJavaType
extends java.lang.Object
    This static class handles all the Informix to Java data conversion. A separate method is provided for converting each IFX data type.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static int DAYS1900
      Constant: number of days between 1/1/0000 and 1/1/1900
      static int DAYS4CENT
      Constant: 365*400 +100-3
      static int DAYS4YEAR
      Constant: 365*4 +1

      • IfxToJavaChar

        public static java.lang.String IfxToJavaChar(byte[] b,
                             int offset,
                             int length,
                             java.lang.String dbEnc,
                             boolean encoption)
                                      throws java.io.IOException
        Convert Informix CHAR (n)/ CHARACTER (n) to Java String Conversion method: Create String from given bytes
        Parameters:
        b - bytes encoding data
        offset - offset into byte array
        length - size of char data
        dbEnc - - JDK encoding
        encoption - - true if IFX_USE_STRENC connection property is set.
        Returns:
        String the string value of the bytes
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • IfxToJavaDate

        public static java.sql.Date IfxToJavaDate(byte[] b)

      • IfxToJavaDate

        public static java.sql.Date IfxToJavaDate(byte[] b,
                          int offset)
        Convert Informix DATE to Java Date IFX date arrives as a long encoding number of days since Dec31, 1899 treated as 0. Negative numbers are allowed and count backwards from the same date. Unfortunately, java.util.Date does NOT yet provide a method to accept "number of days" so need to grind out the yr,month,days triplet. Conversion path: IFX -> long -> Date
        Parameters:
        b - bytes encoding data
        offset - offset into the byte array
        length - data length

      • rleapyear

        public static final boolean rleapyear(int yr)
        checks if yr is a leap year

      • convertDaysToDate

        public static java.sql.Date convertDaysToDate(int dt)
        Does the actual conversion from days -> (yr, date, month)
        Parameters:
        dt - number of days since 1/1/1900 (as 1) Does handle negative days, interp as backwards from 12/31/1899 as 0 No dates before 1/1/0000 allowed, however for now, relies on IFX not generating out of allowed range date.

      • convertDateToDays

        public static int convertDateToDays(java.sql.Date dt)
        Converts java.sql.Date to a int that encodes the number of days since 1/1/1900 (as 1). Dates earlier than that are encoded as negative numbers.
        Parameters:
        dt - java.sql date

      • IfxToJavaDateTime

        public static java.sql.Timestamp IfxToJavaDateTime(byte[] b,
                                   short prec)
        Convert Informix DateTime to Java Timestamp

      • IfxToJavaDateTime

        public static java.sql.Timestamp IfxToJavaDateTime(byte[] b,
                                   int offset,
                                   int length,
                                   short prec)
        Convert Informix DateTime to Java Timestamp Note: IFX DateTime can specify a date in a subset of the full range [YR .. NANOSEC] allowed by Java Timestamp. This creates two problems a. What to do with partial IFX DateTimes when converting to Java Timestamp? Backfill current date? Set unspecified fields to 0? b. How to send Java Timestamp back to IFX when the IFX is only expecting a partial DateTime (based on the precision there). The problem here is how best to preserve the precision info that came from IFX and use it on the way back. See the note " ..." for more details, possible solutions, and solution adopted for now. Conversion path: IFX-> Decimal-> Timestamp
        Parameters:
        b - bytes encoding data
        offset - offset into the byte array
        length - data length
        prec - precision as received from IFX

      • IfxToJavaDateTime

        public static java.sql.Timestamp IfxToJavaDateTime(byte[] b,
                                   int offset,
                                   int length,
                                   short prec,
                                   java.util.Calendar cal)

      • IfxToDateTimeUnloadString

        public static java.lang.String IfxToDateTimeUnloadString(byte[] b,
                                         int offset,
                                         int length,
                                         short prec)
        Convert Informix DateTime to string which is in format compatible with SQL LOAD/UNLOAD format solution adopted for now. Conversion path: IFX-> Decimal-> String
        Parameters:
        b - bytes encoding data
        offset - offset into the byte array
        length - data length
        prec - precision as received from IFX
